title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Joe Biden vowed to “fight like heck” to bolster voting rights across America as the US president called for a narrowing of the racial wealth gap and a recognition of historical injustices on a visit to Tulsa, Oklahoma, the site of one of the most brutal attacks on a black community in American history.

Biden made his remarks in Greenwood, the Tulsa neighbourhood that was known as “Black Wall Street” before a white mob destroyed it killing 300 black people and leaving thousands homeless during a two-day rampage in 1921.

In one of his most extensive speeches on race since becoming president, Biden called for a “month of action” in Congress on voting rights. The call to action comes as Republicans attempt to curb access to voting in many US states they control, including Georgia, Florida and Texas, which critics see as a campaign to limit election participation among black and Hispanic people.

The White House has also pushed for new measures to curb the racial wealth gap in the US, including a crackdown on discrimination in home appraisals and a $100bn boost to federal contracts for small businesses in disadvantaged communities.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis will host a conference today on the impact of racism on entrepreneurs. It is part of a series of events on understanding the implications of structural racism in the US economy.

Coronavirus digest

  • Brazil's gross domestic product expanded faster than expected in the first quarter, bringing Latin America's largest economy back to where it was before the pandemic struck at the end of 2019. Australia's economy has recovered fully from its Covid-19 recession as well, it was revealed on Wednesday.

  • G7 countries have allocated more than $189bn of pandemic recovery funds in support of fossil fuels, despite government pledges to “build back greener” and cut carbon emissions.

  • Hundreds of US universities and colleges have made full vaccination mandatory for students who want to live and study on campus in the autumn. The requirement is dividing students.

  • The UK on Tuesday recorded no daily deaths from Covid-19 for the first time since the start of the pandemic.

  • The Indonesian government is considering sending thousands of Jakarta-based civil servants to work remotely from Bali, in a bid to help the economy of the tourism-reliant island.

Follow our live coronavirus blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

In the news

Oil prices rally The price of Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, rose almost 3 per cent on Tuesday to $71.34 a barrel after Opec and its allies stuck with their plan to gradually increase output into a strengthening oil market. The rollout of vaccines and government stimulus measures have increased demand for oil, helping propel crude prices up 35 per cent since the end of last year. 

  • Go deeper: Anjli Raval, senior energy correspondent, spoke to the FT's News Briefing podcast about Opec's plans to increase production and what it means for the oil market.

Lawsuit alleges Leon Black raped and harassed Russian model The former chief executive of Apollo Global Management, has been hit with a lawsuit claiming that he raped and harassed a young Russian model before manipulating her with promises of money and sham job interviews at Goldman Sachs.

SEC to avoid enforcement of Trump-era proxy adviser rules Gary Gensler, US Securities and Exchange Commission chair, on Tuesday said he asked staff to revisit restrictions for proxy advisers that the commission adopted in July 2020, dealing a blow to companies such as ExxonMobil that have argued services such as ISS and Glass Lewis wield too much power. 

Credit Suisse plots lawsuit against SoftBank Credit Suisse is preparing for litigation against SoftBank after the collapse of Greensill Capital soured the relationship between the Swiss bank and one of the world's largest tech investors, according to people briefed on the plans.

Facebook employees demand changes around Palestinian content Close to 200 Facebook employees have signed an open letter, seen by the Financial Times, calling for the company's leadership to address concerns that pro-Palestine voices on the social network are being suppressed by content moderation systems.

US: Russian gang probably hacked meat supplier A criminal organisation that is probably based in Russia was the origin of a ransomware attack that disrupted animal slaughtering at the world's largest meat processor, the White House said on Tuesday. Reduced operations threatened to curtail beef supplies and drive up prices.

Naomi Osaka challenges sporting norms The tennis star's withdrawal from the French Open over post-match press duties has highlighted how a generation of top athletes is challenging the power of the leagues they work for and advocating for social change. Get our must-read briefing on the business of sport with our Scoreboard newsletter, delivered Saturdays.

The day ahead

Fed publishes its Beige Book The US central bank releases its monthly summary of economic conditions based on anecdotal evidence from a network of agents across the country. 

Walmart's annual meeting Investors will vote on proposals including how much the retailer should pay executives, and whether it should produce reports on its lobbying activities and racial justice goals.

‘Green Swan' conference Many of the world's top central bankers, including Jay Powell of the US Federal Reserve, the People's Bank of China's Yi Gang and president of the European Central Bank Christine Lagarde will speak at a virtual conference on how to tackle climate risks in finance.

Israeli opposition talks deadline Opposition parties in Israel have until midnight to form a coalition and force Benjamin Netanyahu from office. If they succeed, Naftali Bennett, a 49-year old tech millionaire, could become the Jewish state's new prime minister. 

What else we're reading

Why central bankers no longer agree how to handle inflation After years of setting interest rates on the basis of inflation forecasts and seeking to hit a target of about 2 per cent, the leading monetary authorities around the world are pursuing different pandemic strategies. This is the second part in a series on whether inflation is back for good.

Football's search for the ‘Asian fan' The concept of the “Asian fan” was prominent in the business plan for the attempted breakaway European Super League. Its giddying projections about the audience in the world's most populous continent was seen as a driver of the initiative. But it failed to understand the Asian market and the power of stadium-going local fans.

A windfall for poor countries is within reach The world is close to agreeing on the creation of up to $650bn in special drawing rights within the IMF. It is possible to reallocate a proportion of the benefits to global purposes, above all, helping low-income countries restore their pandemic-battered prospects. This opportunity must be seized, writes Martin Wolf.

AI prompts scramble for healthcare data Covid-19 has opened the eyes of the healthcare world to the promise of artificial intelligence, forcing national and commercial health systems to rely on remote medicine and real-time dashboards to spot looming needs. We are seeing a rush to gain access to medical data and turn AI loose upon it, writes Brooke Masters.

How the world ran out of everything Japanese carmaker Toyota is falling victim to a historic advance in industrial efficiency that it helped pioneer. Just In Time manufacturing helps companies save money by minimising the need to stockpile supplies but Covid-19 has disrupted the strategy. (NYT)

An upstate utopia in New York Hutton bricks are baked into some of New York's most iconic landmarks, from the Yankee Stadium to the Empire State Building. Now one of its former production sites, located where the Hudson Valley meets the Catskills, has been turned into a hotel “eerily well-aligned to post-pandemic hospitality.”
